name: ConfIDent-schema
description: This is a schema for the ConfIDent project that describes the necessary metadata requirements of academic events and event series.
title: ConfIDent metadata schema - v0.0.1

types.name: float
types.description: A real number that conforms to the xsd:float specification

types.name: double
types.description: A real number that conforms to the xsd:double specification

types.name: decimal
types.description: A real number with arbitrary precision that conforms to the xsd:decimal specification

types.name: time
types.description: A time object represents a (local) time of day, independent of any particular day
notes: URI is dateTime because OWL reasoners don't work with straight date or time

types.name: date
types.description: a date (year, month and day) in an idealized calendar
notes: URI is dateTime because OWL reasoners don't work with straight date or time

types.name: datetime
types.description: The combination of a date and time

types.name: objectidentifier
types.description: A URI or CURIE that represents an object in the model.
comments: Used for inheritence and type checking

types.name: nodeidentifier
types.description: A URI, CURIE or BNODE that represents a node in a model.

enums.name: EventFormat
enums.description: The permissible values defined in this enum class represent the most common minimal event format specifications. For event formats that are not in this list, you can use "other" and provide the label of this other event format as strind using [other_format](https://stroemphi.github.io/ConfIDent-schema/academicEvent__other_format/).

permissible_values.description: A colloquium is an academic meeting that usually lasts only a few hours and serves to discuss a specific topic. Colloquia are usually part of the academic exchange in everyday university life with only one speaker, but can also take place on special occasions (anniversaries, start or end of the lecture phase, etc.) and can have more than one speaker.

A conference is an academic event that lasts up to several days and serves as a forum for presentations on a specific topic or subject area. In addition to subject-specific conferences, there are also interdisciplinary conferences which allow both a broader focus and more specific questions on a particular (academic) problem. Conferences often have a highly formalized structure of parallel, clearly defined sessions with several short presentations and plenary sessions with invited (keynote) speakers who are considered multipliers in their (research) field. Ideally, the selection of the speakers and their contributions is subject to a review process.

A congress is a certain type of conference which is characterised by a larger number of participants (often several hundred) and is oftentimes organised jointly by large, established (e.g. specialised societies) and/or several institutions. Congresses have a broader thematic focus than simple conferences, take place in certain cycles, but can still target an exclusive group of participants (e.g. representatives of a single discipline).

A session is a clearly defined part of a academic event in which a small number of speakers (usually 2-5) focus on a specific topic. A session is usually formally accompanied by a session chair, who assumes the function of a moderator.
A poster session is a session at which poster papers are presented.
A talk is a central part of a larger academic event, at which a specific topic is being presented in a rather short way.
A keynote speech is a special talk that has the function to set the underlying tone and summarize the core message or most important revelation of the academic event at which it is given.

An academic event that, as a part of a larger academic event, has the function to group even smaller parts of the academic event, like sessions and talks, according to a shared theme or topic. It usually has dedicated chairs and program committees.
An academic event whose sociocultural format is determined in an academic event type specification that classifies the academic event as a forum.
A hackathon is a gathering of software developers with the goal to develop software collaboratively in a short timeframe.

A seminar can serve as a term for older conference series, but in current usage the term mainly describes a specific teaching format that serves to develop content and provides space for discussion. Participation from the audience is usually encouraged.

A symposium is a specific type of conference with a narrower thematic focus, with fewer participants and of shorter duration. The degree of structuring lies between a classic conference and a workshop, allows more discussion than the larger conference, but is usually more formalized than the workshop.
An academic event that has the function to educate the audience on a certain topic. A tutorial is often realized as an academic event talk or academic event session.

Workshops are smaller academic events that serve to exchange information on a specific topic or problem. They usually last one or two days and offer space for discussion and the development of content and solutions. Group work is often part of the event concept.

This value is to be used if the event format cannot be represented using one of the other permissible values defined in the [EventFormat](https://stroemphi.github.io/ConfIDent-schema/EventFormat/) enum. If this value is chosen the use of [other_format](https://stroemphi.github.io/ConfIDent-schema/academicEvent__other_format/) is mandatory.
Default: used to indicate that the event takes place as planned.
The event takes place in a physical location.
The event takes place in a virtual location.
The event takes place physically and virtually.
This value is to be used, if the other allowed values are not applicable.
If true then the event is accessible for people with impairments.

slots.name: id
slots.description: a property to provide the internal id of a schema entity

slots.name: external_id
slots.description: a property to provide the internal id of a schema entity

slots.name: doi
slots.description: A digital object identifier (DOI) according to https://doi.org/.

slots.name: aliases
slots.description: A property to be used to provide alternative names as strings.

slots.name: schema_base_uri
slots.description: The base URI of a schema.

slots.name: type
slots.description: an abstract property used to specify the type of a thing

slots.name: landing_page
slots.description: The website to which a persistent identifier is linking and which contains all the metadata about an academic event or series.

slots.name: dates
slots.description: A property refering to a date container that holds the start date, end date and status of a planned process.

slots.name: contact
slots.description: The contact person of an academic event or event series.

slots.name: outputs
slots.description: The published works that are related to the academic event or event series, such as proceedings and video recordings of talks.

slots.name: academic_fields
slots.description: A property used to describe the scientific subject of the planned process according to some controlled vocabulary or thesaurus. Requires the as subproperties the name and if possible the URL of the identifiying scheme.

slots.name: academicEventSeries__series_of
slots.description: The relation used to provide the events belonging to an AcademicEventSeries.

slots.name: academicEvent__event_format
slots.description: The sociocultural event format which is specified by the organizers, e.g. conference. Possible values are defined in the EventFormat enum, which uses the named individuals defined in AEON.

slots.name: academicEvent__event_mode
slots.description: The event mode describes whether the event is a physical, virtual or hybrid event.

slots.name: academicEvent__at_location
slots.description: The location of the academic event.

slots.name: academicEvent__in_series
slots.description: The relation used to provide the series of which an AcademicEvent is a part.

slots.name: academicEvent__ordinal
slots.description: The ordnial number of an academic event within its series.

slots.name: academicEvent__deadlines
slots.description: A property to deadline_type is mandatory.

slots.name: date__start_date
slots.description: The start date of an academic event or event series. Wheres the latter will in reality most likely be the start date of the first event of this series, unless there is some other source from which it is possible to derive the date of the inception of the series.

slots.name: date__end_date
slots.description: Similar to start_date but only for the end of an academic event or event series.

slots.name: date__duration
slots.description: The duration of an event or series which gets automatically derived, if a stard_date and end_date have been provided.

slots.name: processName__official_name
slots.description: The official name of an academic event or series.

slots.name: processName__acronym
slots.description: The official acronym of an academic event or series.

slots.name: processName__former_name
slots.description: The former official name of an academic event or series. Usually this will only be needed in case an academic event series has undergone a name change.

slots.name: processName__translated_name
slots.description: A translation of the official name to be used in different language contexts.

slots.name: deadline__deadline_date
slots.description: The date of a deadline.

slots.name: deadline__deadline_other
slots.description: This property can be used to specify another kind of deadline, if this type of deadline is not within the allowed values of DeadlineType.

slots.name: contactPerson__email
slots.description: The email address of the contact person.

slots.name: contactPerson__telephone
slots.description: The telephone number of the contact person.

slots.name: confIDentRecords__events
slots.description: An attribute that specifies a list of academic events within this container.

slots.name: confIDentRecords__series
slots.description: An attribute that specifies a list of academic event series within this container.

slots.name: PlannedProcess_name
slots.description: This property is used to provide a name of the academic event or series, which itself has further properties to specify its type (e.g. official name, acronym, etc).

slots.name: AcademicEvent_website
slots.description: the official website of an academic event

slots.name: WikidataId_schema_base_uri
slots.description: The base URI of a schema.

slots.name: GndId_schema_base_uri
slots.description: The base URI of a schema.

slots.name: TibkatId_schema_base_uri
slots.description: The base URI of a schema.

slots.name: DblpId_schema_base_uri
slots.description: The base URI of a schema.

slots.name: WikiCfpId_schema_base_uri
slots.description: The base URI of a schema.

slots.name: EventFormatSpecification_id
slots.description: a property to provide the internal id of a schema entity

slots.name: Deadline_type
slots.description: The type of deadline.

slots.name: Metric_type
slots.description: an abstract property used to specify the type of a thing

slots.name: ProcessRelation_type
slots.description: an abstract property used to specify the type of a thing

slots.name: ContactPerson_id
slots.description: a property to provide the internal id of a schema entity

classes.name: PlannedProcess
classes.description: Abstract base class for academic events and event series.

classes.name: AcademicEventSeries
classes.description: An academic event series describes the set of academic events which take place on a regular basis and thus have an established common identity. This identity is constituted, for example, through institutional continuity in the hosting of a series (e.g. by a specialised society), thematic focuses and/or a common label under which a series is defined (particularly name and acronym). Nevertheless, it is possible that each of these criteria may change over time.

attributes.name: series_of
attributes.description: The relation used to provide the events belonging to an AcademicEventSeries.

classes.name: AcademicEvent
classes.description: An academic event is part of the established instruments of science communication as a format for conveying the latest scientific outputs. It is defined by the meeting of researchers at a specific time and place (virtual or physical) and with a specific thematic focus to present, hear and discuss these outputs. In contrast to other forms of events, academic events should primarily serve the exchange of results and methods of scientific research and their didactic mediation.  Furthermore, a significant participation of scientific organizations in the realization of an academic event is constitutive for this type of event; for example, to distinguish it from events in which researchers mainly act as external experts or with a purely legitimising function.

attributes.name: event_format
attributes.description: The sociocultural event format which is specified by the organizers, e.g. conference. Possible values are defined in the EventFormat enum, which uses the named individuals defined in AEON.

attributes.name: event_mode
attributes.description: The event mode describes whether the event is a physical, virtual or hybrid event.

attributes.name: at_location
attributes.description: The location of the academic event.

attributes.name: in_series
attributes.description: The relation used to provide the series of which an AcademicEvent is a part.

attributes.name: ordinal
attributes.description: The ordnial number of an academic event within its series.

attributes.name: deadlines
attributes.description: A property to deadline_type is mandatory.

classes.name: Date
classes.description: A container for the start and end date, the date status as well as the duration of a planned process.

attributes.name: start_date
attributes.description: The start date of an academic event or event series. Wheres the latter will in reality most likely be the start date of the first event of this series, unless there is some other source from which it is possible to derive the date of the inception of the series.

attributes.name: end_date
attributes.description: Similar to start_date but only for the end of an academic event or event series.

attributes.name: duration
attributes.description: The duration of an event or series which gets automatically derived, if a stard_date and end_date have been provided.

attributes.name: official_name
attributes.description: The official name of an academic event or series.

attributes.name: acronym
attributes.description: The official acronym of an academic event or series.

attributes.name: former_name
attributes.description: The former official name of an academic event or series. Usually this will only be needed in case an academic event series has undergone a name change.

attributes.name: translated_name
attributes.description: A translation of the official name to be used in different language contexts.

classes.name: WikidataId
classes.description: The identifier of a thing (item) in Wikidata.

classes.name: GndId
classes.description: The identifier of a thing (item) in the German National authority file.

classes.name: TibkatId
classes.description: The identifier of a publication in the TIB catalog.

classes.name: DblpId
classes.description: The identifier of an academic event or series in dblp.

classes.name: WikiCfpId
classes.description: The identifier of an academic event or series in WikiCFP.

classes.name: EventFormatSpecification
classes.description: An academic event format specification is a plan specification that classifies a planned gathering of people in an academic context according to some sociocultural format, which provides implicit and explicit details on how this gathing is to be carried out by its participants in terms of achieving certain objectives, fulfiling certain conditions and performing certain actions. It thus concretizes the expectations of the contributers of an academic event. While the explicit details are often provied as concrete parts (e.g. deadline or attendance fee specifications), the implicit details depend on the semantics encoded in the words used for the classification of academic events (e.g. "conference" or "workshop"). Depending on the sociocultural background these classifications can overlap or vary to a certain degree.

attributes.name: deadline_date
attributes.description: The date of a deadline.

attributes.name: deadline_other
attributes.description: This property can be used to specify another kind of deadline, if this type of deadline is not within the allowed values of DeadlineType.

classes.name: AcademicField
classes.description: An academic field is the scientific subject of the planned process according to some controlled vocabulary or thesaurus and as such requires the scheme URI.

attributes.name: email
attributes.description: The email address of the contact person.

attributes.name: telephone
attributes.description: The telephone number of the contact person.

classes.name: ConfIDentRecords
classes.description: This is a container to be able to bundle academic event and series data in one data file (e.g. YAML or JSON).

attributes.name: events
attributes.description: An attribute that specifies a list of academic events within this container.

attributes.name: series
attributes.description: An attribute that specifies a list of academic event series within this container.
